A1BoRYMtfPAbufpMjznpCA.text: Happy, homey vegetarian food. This place is one of my favourite places to eat in the world. The prices are reasonable, as the portions are generous, and the food is great quality.  Don't eat all day, and order all 3 courses, plus a bottle of wine. You won't regret starving.The Chef's Salad is amazing, especially if you opt for the tofu instead of feta (cheese lovers out there, I know, but really. GET THE TOFU). It's such a delight to get that big old salad, and pick around underneath for all the hidden bits. It's divine.The deserts are insane, especially when they have a lemon torte. The crumble with custard is always a good fallback.And for all you silly star spotters out there, this is where everyone famous, American and British, dine. I won't spoil it for you by telling who.

LbrYfpQtrF4DjsDRguNHhQ.text: Sorry to be a downer, but on an absolute scale and after sampling the menu extensively, the food is terrible. Cons: Vegan options that try to be meat substitutes (eg, veatballs  dry and flavourless); Manna does much better with the menu items that are comfortable as the I am vegan options that they are. The pan-asian style items seem to offer the best flavour profiles. Pros: Attentive service, family atmosphere, and most of all, according to my vegan friends, the only real restaurant in London that offers a proper full vegan menu. So, for that, I applaud Manna. But if you do not mind being limited to a few items on the menu, other restaurants score higher on taste.

rTpewhXywXFK3ciLpczHRQ.text: Very disappointed in food and service after reading all the raving reviews here. I went here for Thanksgiving as an American living in London. As a devout vegan for 14+ years I thought I'd give it a try. Firstly- the service is terrible. All of the servers are incredibly rude. My husband and I were one of the first people to be sat down and we were sat next to the door which I requested if we could have a table closer to a wall because I have a cold and asthma and did not want to have an asthma attack on thanksgiving. After explaining this to the server/hostess she just rudely said "no" even though at this point the restaurant was empty. She said the tables were reserved for other people- as if people know where they are going to sit? My husband and I also had reservations. None of the servers had any respect for this holiday. The food was so/so. The only course I liked was the pumpkin soup. The salad was bland. The thanksgiving nut roast course was not good at all- the roast itself was very gummy and tasteless. It tasted like raw dough. The pumpkin cheesecake was too rich and once again tasted gummy. I've been vegan for 14+ years and this was by far the worst meal I've ever had. This is very disappointing because I had such high hopes. Perhaps if the service was warmer, kinder, and trained in customer service I wouldn't have noticed the bland food as much. Usually vegan/vegetarian places are friendly and welcoming....not upsetting and rude.

hGtDBClH7EfXjAP7vu3uWQ.text: Very enjoyable and if only there were more around. Even our non-veggie friends loved the food. Thank you.

kd12irE3MO4ceDWCjXHNLA.text: NOT TO BE MISSED IF YOU ARE IN LONDON !!!!Recommended by my vegan sister and her veggie husband, then reinforced by a non-veggie boss.  Definitely worth the trip out to Primrose Hill!  It was a pre-birthday dinner and we were hungry after walking around Camden town then stopping at the local Pembroke pub while waiting for our reservation (second seating was the only one available).  We tried three starters - the bonga and ragada plate which was excellent, the under-named ravioli which were good but the standout was the butternut squash tart - next time I will order a full tart for dinner!! For entrees, we had the pasta special - pesto and tasty but the winner was the enchiladas - incredible!!  The espinaca was a bit stringy, but the sweet potato and pumpkin seed (one of my favorite foods!!) filling was wonderful.  No need for the rice side and the guacomole and salsa were fine, nothing extraordinaire but it was almost winter in the UK so probably not as good as when tomatoes are in season.  The bread selection was great (our entrees took some time after the starters) but he beetroot hummus was stunning - color - and tasted fine.  For dessert we had the tiramasu and the baked-stuffed apple.  Fortunately, as I don't like walnuts, they were replaced with pecans, and the "vice" cream was yummy.  One of the highlights of the meal was the mint/citrus infusion (tea-like) at the end of the meal - sweetened with maple syrup it was an amazing end to a fantastic meal.

NMvR8sCMBXn8f0WxUQ1pgw.text: Oh, Manna, how appropriately named you truly are, and how long I waited to find out! I'm really not sure why it took me so many years of living in London as a vegetarian and then a vegan to get round to eating at Manna. Perhaps it was being slightly put off by a friend who described it as posh and pricey, perhaps it was not quite knowing where Primrose Hill was...whatever, I couldn't be more pleased that just a couple of months ago I had the pleasure of visiting with some friends before seeing Martha Wainwright play round the corner at The Roundhouse. That's where Primose Hill is, righhhhht... I suppose Manna is sort of posh and sort of pricey, but only if 'posh' means nice, and 'pricey' means paying more than you would for okay food to receive gorgeously lovely food. All the food is vegetarian and lots of it is also vegan, and the staff (unlike another, similarly priced, vegetarian/vegan restaurant in Soho) are very sweet. A very handsome young chap of a waiter even declined to laugh in my face when I couldn't work out how to get the salt out of the dual salt/pepper grinder - now that's manners! Oh, what a terrible pun I just made, quite unwittingly...manners = mannas, geddit? Looking at their website (mannav.com) they've got a load of deals on at the moment so my next trip might be sooner than I'd planned...YUM.

nFkLqLAfE8SFUYuE-bNijQ.text: I am going to have to agree with evelyn on this, I went there for dinner, and I found the food just competant and uninteresting, I had the chefs special spagetthi and "meatballls" quite a safe choice but I figured it was chefs special so it must be exciting. Wasn't the case.  The ambience and service were great. But for the prices they are charging the food is not upto scratch at all.

N88Wz3V9k2AXsDtRSaAVKw.text: We ate here for Valentines Day a couple years back, when visiting London.  The food was incredible, but what stands out most were the chocolate truffles they sent us home with in a cute little box.  Best truffles I've ever tried!  And vegan to boot!  Can't wait for our next trip :)

7BkfttVcDdr0CWN81pb7sw.text: Considering im not a lover of veggies, this place was quite an interesting place to eat. There could have been a bit more choice but i would definately go back there.

OC4Tf83Rbe44UZykTY2IgQ.text: Delicious restaurant for vegan people (or not), especially good for Saturday or Sunday brunch when you can grab a table outside or in the conservatory. The food it very good, you can eat Organic tortilla espanola, goats cheese, creme fraiche and coriander basmati rice cake, organic asparagus, pea and lettuce tart and a devilish rich squidgy chocolate cakemmmmI'm not a vegan but I loved this place, would definately go again!

Pr0vopmWJQo_sPDiz6k-2A.text: This has to be one of my favourite takeaways at lunch time. They do some awesome salads in which you put together your own salad the way you like it from their salad bar. For £5 you get a huge salad bowl, nice and healthy! They also sell sadwhiches and other hot food.

pm7otugy5vAklvPOvIAd5A.text: Nice, rather elegant, in elegant Primrose Hill nabe. Food was good, but not too special. My teenage son loved the Knicikerbocker Glory, a parfait of fruits and ice cream, not too veggie-ish.

ZhCoCumWtQwQDoS2zRQnsQ.text: This is a very good place to eat, especially if you are a vegetarian like me. There aren't many vegetarian shops in this area, so this is a brilliant place, and the food is absolutely delicious.

suiwuKXIfpRvY8ra1Ge3Cg.text: Excellent food; imaginative menu and well executed. Nice ambience and helpful staff. Linen napkins also a plus. But they really need to lose the pub wine glasses.

kQ1hpmtMOUIxKpT1PR2CcQ.text: Great assortment of food--everything is delicious! The restaurant space itself is also very warm and inviting.I was visiting from NYC, where vegan and GF restaurants are everywhere--so I was pleasantly surprised when this place put all my NYC experiences to shame.I'm gluten free, and I went with 2 other girls, one vegetarian, and the other with no dietary restrictions. My friend who eats everything even agreed it was a surprisingly delicious (meatless) meal.Between us we ordered mostly small sides and starters.  My favorites were the cannellini bean slider and the seasonal mash with gravy. We all shared the tiramisu cheesecake for dessert and it was AH-MAZING. Wish this place was in the same country as me so I could visit more frequently!

IlJJ-iuiD1vJ73_P66y2MQ.text: Absolutely outstanding food! Whenever we go to London, Manna is one of our first stops!

o10-pD0GSTh1ALLmKCIySg.text: I think the 5-star reviews must be from vegetarians desperate for more menu options when they go out. I was really disappointed that all the menu options were for recipes that traditionally have meat, rather than real vegetarian recipes that aren't trying to substitute any "missing ingredients". (For example Ottolenghi has much more innovative, complete vegetarian options.) However the atmosphere is cosy and it's certainly not a bad place to spend an evening with vegetarians. It's also kid-friendly.

WzgKUiKSVKZ_u1SQ_ksaAg.text: I attended Manna's Thanksgiving feast last week and was absolutely impressed. The food was delicious and, short of my mother's cooking, was all that I could have asked for to satisfy my nostalgia for traditional Thanksgiving food. Not only that, but their preparation of tempeh turkey meant that, FINALLY, I was able to have a taste of the main course that everyone always raves about. The selection was fantastic. My friend and I were served an aperitif, pumpkin soup, salad, wine, the above mentioned turkey, mash, green beans and pearl onions, sweet potatoes, mushroom gravy, cranberry sauce, AND to top it all off, dessert! The service was wonderful and the atmosphere is adorable. The food is more expensive than I would usually go for but now I will be tempted to splurge every once in a while to come visit. Very nice results on a traditional American holiday, London!

Chy0jdIbUrLgZ_JMc0E6XA.text: I've dined at Manna thrice (always aiming for the traditional Sunday roast time) and every moment has been wonderfully memorable. The service is both prompt and sweet; the atmosphere is nature-inspired and relaxing; the owner is a most delightful host. This past weekend the soup of the day was the most glorious and piping hot wild mushroom and fennel treat served with tiny, fresh-from-the-oven rolls. The meze platter is a great idea: a little of everything. The croquettes are quite amazing; as I enjoy them I try to imagine how the chefs get that soft cashew cheese filling inside the perfectly round, crisp spheres...and then there are the raviolis stuffed with walnut pâté, and graced with two gorgeous sauces. The portions are so generous it can be hard to save room for dessert but the long, tall trifle can be shared by two.Manna's guest books (a new one's just been started) contain grateful notes from people all over the world - vegans and non-vegans alike - who have never had a lovelier meal.  Their praise is well earned and deserved. Check the map well. Though very near Chalk Farm Station, Manna is located in a small road tucked away rather snugly; it's actually quite easy to find, though, after a stroll through Regent's Park coming north into Primrose Hill. Manna is unique, and a model for anyone wanting to start a vegan restaurant that treats its guests with genuine care. The world needs more wonderful places like this to visit, enjoy, remember, and revisit as soon as possible! [The reviewer blogs at veganplace.wordpress.com and co-authored the cookbook Dining With Friends: The Art of North American Vegan Cuisine.]

2qmN4Ds9nxk2M2cdb5KdOQ.text: As a visitor to London, i've only been to Manna once for dinner - but I was mightily impressed at that one visit! For starters, it's a lovely environment - beautiful decor, a cosy little space (even with a tiny conservatory!), and a small bar if you need somewhere to sit and wait for a table (like we did, but not for too long!). The staff when it's a bit busy can be a bit hard to get a hold of, but they are absolutely helpful, friendly and attentive when dealing with you. Let's face it - i'd not really heard much about the restaurant itself, but the food - that's what I went there for, that's what made a killer impression on me. There's a good selection of stuff on the menu without being overwhelming, and a chef's special each day if it takes your fancy. (They have quite a nice selection at the bar as well, if you take a drink with your dinner.) The presentation is impeccable for the appetisers and mains, and the portion sizes are a reasonable size for what is essentially a gourmet-style restaurant.I shared a meze plate of appetisers with my friend, because I couldn't decide what I wanted - the three we chose were the raw pad thai salad (nice and spicy), smoky tofu & potato roulade, and grilled tikka kebabs (which I could've eaten about 20 plates of and still wanted more, oh so delicious!). My friend tried the chef's special which was a nice indian take on shepherd's pie  - a really fantastic and unusual use of flavours. I was lured in by the onion rings and tried the bangers and mash - terrific gravy and an incredibly creamy mash, very fresh (I guess made on premises?) veggie sausages and those delectable onion rings on top. The only thing that irked me was the fennel in the sausages - but i'm not a lover of that flavour. I could barely finish my main, so disappointingly I couldn't try dessert at the restaurant - I was dangerously close to exploding. We got a fantastic selection of the petit fours packed up to go which I tried the next day, and they are definitely a delicious treat! One day i'll get back and try that banoffee trifle though..Thanks for the meal and the evening, Manna! I wouldn't hesitate to come back for lunch *or* dinner when I happen to be in London next.

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Petit four - we had to take this to go because we were too full!
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Tower of delicious - veggie bangers and mash
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Indian-style shepherd's pie

VY0RBOjeYq-1rUAVh23gJQ.text: We went last night for a belated birthday meal, starter was nice, we had the raw pad Thai. It could do with some coriander. I had the build my own mains although I would like to have the banger and mash! Wholesome food, generous portion. Dessert was lovely and staff are very friendly. A good choice for vegan and vegetarians!

EP_jSisydtCBLaufH42-3g.text: I wish there were more vegetarian restaurants like manna; classy without being contrived, intimate and candlelit, food that is fresh and artfully presented... and oh yeah, *yawn*, they happen not to serve meat.  Too many veggie restaurants seem to think that catering to vegetarians also means they have to try and teleport you back to the 70s hippie movement with offerings of wheatgrass and macrame decor that won't for an instant let you forget that YOU ARE IN A VEGGIE RESTAURANT AND YOU ARE NOT EATING MEAT!  X PEACE XOy.  Just because I'm a vegetarian doesn't mean I don't like graceful service and smart surroundings.  Manna gets this - thank you.Now, about the food.  Everything we ate was delicious, but I *really* wish I'd ordered the creole sweet potato galette after tasting it... spicy, packed with an array of vegetables... it was everything you could possibly want from a dish.  Also,  the chef salad sounded amazing, but I really don't like mayo, and our waiter's description had me envisioning a cloying mayo-drenched potato salad... but the table next to us had one and it looked more green and fresh than mayo-laden.... so next time!As a whole, a very fantastic experience.  A cozy atmosphere full of panache, downright tantalizing food and unpretentious attentive service -  you would never know you were in a "vegetarian" restaurant.  I will keep going back until I have tried *everything.*

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. ze entrance

QyAX_vv7udeYYdF_TZu4_Q.text: Manna is pricey, but you definitely get interesting choices and creative menu options. I do wish the food had been better seasoned, but I find this true in most London restaurants. For my money, Saf (off of Old Street) is a better find.

0025lrVbu-X5M0ae5PFMsw.text: Vegetarian food here is eclectic and quite good overall. The Indian salad and the vegetable tempura were particularly tasty. Service is attentive and the place is intimate. They sell a variety of freshly squeezed juices.

pzz-5RkJXPZVVmigzeTBmA.text: Just because a restaurant is vegan...does it mean we can give them a handicap of +5 points?  Rhetorical question.Gluten-free bread and beetroot infused hummus (magenta), combined with a vegetarian burrito with some seriously legit salsa = health all up in my BODY.  All things were surprisingly tasty albeit hard to chew due to all that fiber between my teeth.  But together with a coconut/blueberry shake and amounting to about 35 squids for lunch, the price wasn't that right.Atmosphere wise, expect the typical Prissy Hill crowd and their blue-ribbon dogs chained to the legs of their outdoor chairs.  Lovely and relaxed though, just don't expect supremo stomach satisfaction if you belong to the more carnivorous side of life.

9IfSi8AWDKyf9dMXNAofhg.text: It took me a while to define 3 or 4 stars, as I think I have a bit of mixed feelings. The decor and ambient is lovely, staff is friendly though reading the reviews and thinking I can imagine who could be the moody waiters. Food was nice but not astonishing! I have a great truffle & champagne risotto for starter, loved but main dish, beans and polenta was okay. My friends appreciated their food! I think it is worth to give it a try!

FIQPpIYSyXKOhTgyKGDcDQ.text: The food here was quite tasty, if a bit heavy. The prices are extremely high, but the quality of the food and its presentation justify the prices. This is one of the fancier vegetarian restaurants in London, and it has a good selection of vegan dishes as well. I highly recommend trying their desserts, especially the vegan cheesecake, which is one of the best I've had in the world.The service was passable, but not great. Our waitress hurried us out of the restaurant once we were finished. This type of customer "service" is something I am not accustomed to, being American, but I've since heard it's common in the UK, so I won't subtract any stars for it.

0CfeBywk3RQGNVDoj4_wEg.text: Service was good, nice cosy place with nice lighting. Starters were pretty good. The croquettes were very good, the tempura average and the artichoke starter was a bit flavourless. There was a stone in the tapenade and the artichoke was the texture of hard avocado. The mains were a let down. The Caribbean platter had fluffy rice full of flavour but the curry was pretty bland and like something you could whip up fairly quickly at home. The slaw was very dry and I can't imagine anyone enjoying pineapple salsa. The mix of pineapple with onion gave off the taste of durian which is a required taste.The sausage and mash was pretty average as well. The shepard's pie was less impressive. Both being like something I've had as a veggie main in a pub for half the price. We had some sides. The greens (kale) were okay and the deep fried tofu was flavourless. We really wanted to enjoy it and maybe we picked the wrong mains but it felt very over priced considering nothing really blew us away. I'd probably pop in and try the other mains for half the price but for £14 I feel like I'm just paying for the convenience of vegan food above anything else that seemed like veggie pub food on a square plates.Servers were very nice and helpful which can turn an average evening into a better one.

CInGCw5cmwU4UWjI2xhiQw.text: Cant agree more with the tag "best vegetarian restaurant in London". Went there for Sunday lunch with my parents (non-veg) and we were all amazed of the wide selection of dishes and how good, tasty and fresh everything was. We had the mushroom tempura, indonesian satay, autumn salad, risotto strudel and sunday roast, and even if we were full, we had to order dessert, everything tasted so good that we didnt want to miss anything. I also loved the fact that is vegan, so perfect for poor lactose-intolerant people like myself Was a bit pricey (hence the 4 stars instead of 5), but definitely worth it. My parents have already asked me to go back there the next time they come to London...as my dad said, "I didnt know vegetarian food could be so amazing". Will be back, hopefully very soon

OxNxvyOxL77fT9iAfUa79w.text: My feelings on Manna fluctuate for all sorts of reasons.  The food is fairly consistent and tasty (for vegetarian food anyway!), but the service can at times be gruff.  It has a nice cozy atmosphere, a good wine list, and organic vodka which slightly make up for the fact that I spend the next 24 hours after eating here stuffing my face.  Perfect spot for post yoga snacks though.

F7WZt5owRWX44RBRW4kR9g.text: With 3 stars, I'm apparently bucking the trend for Manna reviews but if I'm honest, this place was quite the anticlimax. The decor was lovely, the staff attentive and the atmosphere very comfortable but where the food should have sung a veggie melody, it only whimpered a bland ballad. Sorry for that analogy - I've just been watching the X Factor.Anyway, to start we shared a variety of small dishes because we were all feeling a little too greedy to settle for one dish. My favourite of these starters was the smoked tofu won ton. Never before a tofu fan, this crunchy little surprise has made me rethink years of nose turning. However, from that tasty treat to a very dull 'living lasagne'. Thinly sliced raw beetroot is never going to win any taste prizes, especially not when it's only accompaniments are raw tomato and cashew cheese. Cashew cheese?! If anyone can explain how you milk a cashew I'm all ears. Whatever it is though - it definitely wasn't worth £7.The mains carried on in a very mixed fashion with my falafel reigning supreme and chickpea curry falling far behind. Our vegan desserts were pretty patchy too - the ice cream was good but the blueberry cake was dry. I mean cotton wool on your tongue dry. Bleh.Maybe we just caught Manna on a bad day and so there's potential enough to give it another chance but as far as yum points go, I'm underwhelmed.

CJHV9xjzHXCa_aU9Xf6Wcw.text: for our last meal together, my lovely bro and sis in law took me to manna for an early bday dinner.  i really liked the food here.for starters, we had the mezze platter where you get to choose 3 starters/salads.  we got the fennel and leek soup, the jerk tofu and sweet potato kebabs, and the walnut pate ravioli w/ a side of sundried tomato pesto.  we also had the homemade bread w/ hummus.  i loved the jerk tofu, and the soup and ravioli were also very tasty.for entrees, we shared the bangers and mash and the sunday nut roast.  the mash was delicious and made of carrots, potatoes, dill and chives.  the nut roast w/ roasted potatoes and broccolini were also good.  we then also got a side of garlicky sauteed greens.for dessert, we got the trifle which i loved.  it was vegan so the cream was airy, and the caramel was delicious.  there were also brownie chunks in there and it was plenty for 3 to share.the couple who owns the place is lovely as well.  we chatted w/ the wife a bit, b/c she's also from california and very sweet.  she told us they do a special thanksgiving meal w/ vegan pumpkin pie or cheesecake, which sound delicious.

CrQ7yM2SDpQGcd0XD5rUIg.text: Had a shared platter for the starter and the slider was pretty exceptional. Liked that they had a good balance between the raw and cooked food. Overall nice little place ))) walking home with a smile

TwhwA_BHeqcj8DyipJ7vpQ.text: Now, I'm the kinda girl who struggles to resist temptation at the best of times and when that comes in the form of meat or fish, I'm often too damn weak to say 'no'. However, thankfully on my journey to Manna I had the pleasure of a recently transformed vegetarian who was brimming with the exuberance of the recently converted. Billed just about everywhere as the 'best vegetarian restaurant' in London I was simply gagging to get a last minute reservation, and staff were happily receptive to my pleas. So hungry for meat substitutes and all manner of foliage, my lovely friend and I began the painstaking process of choosing our meal, sampling a selection of grains (their names escape me, I was too engaged in stimulating conversation over a Kir Royale) finalising on a Chef's salad served with crispy marinated tofu, now featuring celeriac, roasted fennel, winter potato salad, raw carrot, raw grated beetroot and many more deliciously tasty treats. I told her I disliked beetroot, but was actually lying as I scoffed several mouthfuls! However, the pièce de résistance had to be the enchilada casserole layered exquisitely with cashew cheese, black beans & rich mole sauce, sandwiching tortillas served with green rice, carrot salsa & guacamole. That dish alone was well worth the Israelites venturing into the wilderness seeking the holy manna. Beautiful company, effortless food and service, jumping straight into my London top ten seamlessly.

P82RHO5xf4NmbS-oQ5_d9Q.text: After dragging my suitcase and carryon all over Hackney in 90F weather to get to another vegan place for a late lunch and sadly finding it was closed, I popped into a local pub and was recommended Manna for dinner.  I had my doubts as I was getting tired and wanted to head out to my lodgings to settle in for the night, and of course I went completely the wrong way when I left the train station (with my 20Kg rolling suitcase) but once I got to Manna... I was warmly welcomed and seated right away.I ordered a glass of sauvignon blanc and started with the arrancini - before my appetizer arrived, the restaurant started to fill up and another singleton arrived but was almost turned away before I invited him to join my table, so we shared dinner at Manna.  Now I have more things to review!  - Arrancini - incredible and delicious, the sauce was so good!- Polenta tart - I've made polenta plenty but never put it in a  pan - this was really a fancy way of doing it, and the salad and herbs in this super creamy polenta was very quiche-like- Bangers & mash - topped with a trio of perfectly crispy onion rings, the homemade vegan sausages were delicious and not totally an analog of meat (not chewy but flavorful) and with baby kale and the most amazing mashed potatoes -- huge portion (I took half of it away to eat on the airplane later)- Chocolate-peanut butter custard -- this was INCREDIBLE -- there's nothing better than chocolate AND peanut butter and this dessert did not disappoint, rich chocolate ganache on top that was creamy/fudgy and not set hard with a rich thick peanut butter custard underneath, topped with candied nuts.  If you go to ONE fancy vegan place for dinner - this should be your choice.  It's not cheap (I paid $65 for app, entree, dessert & two glasses of wine) but service is impeccable and the food is outstanding.

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Polenta torte
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Bangers and mash
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Peanut butter chocolate custard

fW1iSP4SLHX5XRJSdSCUUQ.text: Wish I could of eaten there...I went there at opening and there were only two people ahead of me.They told me that they were not taking any walk ins until 3.5 hours later...right before closing. It bothered me that all the tables but one were open and they could not squeeze me in. Well..the lesson....do not go here unless you have a reservation.

uZqm5VlKXmZvobVg9jtdkQ.text: Manna has a beautiful location and beautiful interior. I was also very impressed with the level of service we had, despite how busy things were. We decided to try a bit of everything and the most recommended dishes- the bangers and mash, nachos, and enchilada. I'm sorry to say but none of the dishes blew me away. Generally when I try "recreations" of meat dishes I'm certainly not expecting them to taste of meat, but I expect them to be delicious. The bangers and mash were warm-ish, which sort of bugged me. The textures started blending together along with the flavours, which sort of made the dish a gooey mess. When looking at the pictures I was expecting piping hot mash, flavourful and thick bangers (yes I just said that) and crunchy hot onion rings. I got none of that. The enchilada had more flavour and spice, which I was thankful for but the depth of flavours was also lacking. Nachos were good.

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Nachos
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Bangers and mash
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Enchilada bake

WET9h3qdzA2Y4cDQeY5dmQ.text: Mostly vegan but with a few vegetarian starters, this restaurant has a down to earth and cosy atmosphere. You won't leave feeling hungry (I know what people think...) so don't worry!! Everything is just delicious!!! Try: nachos, basil and cheese balls, caribbean plate!

hm5ZKkzav7ahTVdOo4Io2g.text: I came to Manna with a friend while visiting London and had a great experience. Their organic bangers and mash was amazing, but my favorite item I ordered was the peanut butter creme. It was spectacular! My only slight complaint is that we were about 5 minutes early for our reservation at 6:30, also when the restaurant opened. It was pouring rain and the staff ignored us until it was exactly 6:30. It seemed a bit rude...it would've been really nice of them to let us wait inside for 5 minutes. Other than that, it was a really nice restaurant and I would certainly go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Peanut butter creme
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Organic Bangers and Mash

rXYXgq9BNPntCcuyvlhO7A.text: Found this gem of a vegetarian spot in London over the weekend. The vibe was fantastic, truly inspiring without being overdone. The staff was friendly and welcoming in a very relaxed way, which felt fitting.My girlfriend and I ordered a "mezza" to share, and were able to pick three appetizers or salads for a reduced price. The Brazilian cashew croquettes made up one of the most delicious small plates I've ever had, sort of a vegetarian's crab rangoon as my girlfriend put it. The vegetarian sushi was good, but definitely needed the soy sauce to come together, and the naked tacos were good despite not being our favorite.The only reason I can't give five stars is because we unfortunately found a dead fly on one of our salad leaves, quite literally attached by the wing somehow. I let the waitress know and this may be when their chill nature may have failed them, as she lightly apologized but it wasn't mentioned again or brought up to a manager. For a restaurant that charges £8-10 for any of these small appetizers, including £9 for only three of those croquettes, I expected much more hospitality for a clear mistake like that.

T26aAt1RV5vQ8E98gRS2LA.text: Lovely vegetarian place with delicious meals.Waiters are friendly.Good thing: you can order "mezze" (3 starters) for around 20 £. I recommend the polenta-tarte and the burger. The pakora and the tostada wasn't that special but was also good.Place is in the upper price range.

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Without sugar and vegan. Special and good.
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. 3 Meeze. Great vegan tarte. I loved it! Pakora and taco tasted similar but good.
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Fantastic vegan Burger! But lots of onions.

1n8W4AWhYFca2sDvVVo8kQ.text: If you are in London, eat at this place. Both my carnivorous boyfriend and I agreed the meal we had here made it into the top five meals we have ever had. While I was there I couldn't help but feel melancholy over not living in London and not knowing when I'd get to eat here again. For starters we had the polenta tart and raw tacos. While both were fantastic, the tacos are a must have. For mains we shared the enchilada lasagna and the bangers and mash. We couldn't decide which we preferred. My boyfriend was amazed at how flavorful the bangers and mash were and said he might be happy to have it over real bangers(which is huge because this guy loves sausages).  After gushing over the food and then lamenting to our server that we were too full for dessert, she brought us three small (and complimentary) vegan chocolate truffles to try. The perfectly delicious end to our meal. Our server told us Manna was the first veg restaurant in London and has been in business 48 years! After enjoying the food you will understand why. Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Enchilada lasagna. A beautiful combo of Mexican and Italian flavors.
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Bangers and mash. So damn good.
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Raw tacos and polenta tart. Both delicious, raw tacos a must.

X-JmaGhwX54CwTIDIob37Q.text: Excellent food, surprisingly filling for a vegetarian restaurant.Anyone can enjoy it, even if you are only accompanying the V person !

_ZvxWYgHt7jwLTqEtl8G-w.text: Went here with some vegetarian friends. They absolutely loved that they could order everything on the menu without restraint or asking questions. I'm sure according to them this place is a 5*We had the nachos to start, and I had the veatball spaghetti for my main. Both aren't as good as their non vegan originals but I must say good try! The ice cream semifreddo is very nice though!

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Semifreddo best thing

yDO_7yYhOru0ROEcSKdf_g.text: Thanksgiving at Manna gave me a home away from home this holiday season. As a vegetarian, it's next to impossible to find somewhere to have a veggie American Thanksgiving in London, but Manna fills that need with a multicourse meal that has everything you could want. Pumpkin soup, salad course, tempeh roast, mashed potato, stuffing, cranberry sauce, green beans, sautéed onions, a dessert of either pumpkin cheesecake or apple pie. My one wish is that they'd make traditional pumpkin pie as it is one of the highlights of the season for me! But regardless, excellent meal in a beautiful environment with a friendly and accommodating staff. All I could have asked for on Thanksgiving.

g9op6oxIQ1pNf3OMPG1Qhg.text: Very nice food with some British classics thrown in for good measure. Would definitely go back!

T8BJ-apREAYwnAzSs7JUwQ.text: I really enjoyed this restaurant. They had yummy food and a pleasant atmosphere. It was in a quaint house type restruant. They have good sized portions as well. They had "vegan cheese balls" I think they called them something better but they were delicious.

IZYTylTjBp-LohtZTZNsRQ.text: I'm a meat-eater, and I love this vegan restaurant.  I've dined here twice so far and had a fantastic experience both times.  Great service and food.  There are so many delicious options on the menu that it is hard to decide what to get! I recommend ordering the following starters: Cannellini bean slider, raw lasagne (note that it is served cold), and the indian pizza.  If you and your guest want to share 3 starters, I recommend ordering the manna meze to share.  With the manna meze, you can order any 3 starters or salads for 22 pounds.  If you go on Sunday, the chef's special is fantastic.  I shared the chef's special nut loaf with kale - It is perfect Sunday comfort food.  I love this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. There she is...
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Sunday nut roast
Photo of Manna - London, United Kingdom. Manna mezze to share (selection of 3 starters)

ToFmsXwzMmPbbkklJoC9Dg.text: Excellent food! The veatball sub is so filling and just tastes fantastic as well as the nachos! Even my non-vegan family members love it!

tDst8X6B4Cq4aZxds1aDPA.text: Food - Pretty damn tasty. Between us, we tried the bangers & mash, Sunday roast and baja california plate. I can especially recommend the roast and baja. The blueberry cheesecake though... strangely rubbery and uncheesecake-like. Not so nice at all.Cost - Thought it was a bit over-priced, sorry Manna. We took the Manna meze for £22 to start and it was teeny tiny. A spoonful of salad, half a miniature cashew cheese croquette each (admittedly, very tasty) and one stick of vegetable tempura. Unhappy face. :(Service - We had a friendly waitress and a rather odd waiter who seemed painfully shy and not at all suited to serving the public. But he had a fantastic afro in which he kept his pencil, and I managed to coax a smile out of him by the end of the night.If I scored a pay rise, I reckon I'd come here again. Otherwise, much as I enjoyed the food, I'll probably stick with other cheaper and tastier veggie options.

-VbbsklJUmMCsn_R54QD2A.text: Food was really good, however the prices were quite high for what we ate, and the service was not good. It was tough to get the waitstaff's attention; when we wanted to order, when we wanted more to drink, when we wanted to see a dessert menu, when we wanted to the bill, and when we wanted to pay. We spent more time waiting to get the staff's attention than enjoying the food. The surprising part is that they were preoccupied wiping utensils - quite loudly, and talking amongst each other. The tacos and soup were really nice.

Bl3nC3pULUCh1nJte9DOug.text: Such perfection! I decided I had to try Manna while I'm living in London even though it's rather expensive. Great decision! I had the (vegan) bangers and mash and it was so much better than the original I remember from my pre-vegan days. My friend had the enchilada lasagne, which was delicious as well. The portions were large enough to sate us and to keep us from ordering dessert. The wine was quite nice as well, a maybe that paired nicely with my meal. I'm so satisfied with my experience at Manna and hopefully will make it back someday!

8ikUU8yiSak-YzasdpezLw.text: I was so happy to wander off the main Primrose Hill strip of restaurants and find Manna V. We popped in on a Friday and they were all booked up, so we made a reservation for the following night as were set on trying it. They have a varied vegan menu with good raw options as well (like Raw lasagne). Our food was excellent and the waitstaff were very attentive. They have a great wine and dessert list to boot. Can't wait to go back.

VyDk3pugVDyfD-XuSE_7Gw.text: I can't wait to go back to Manna the next I'm in town! Went there with my omnivorous boyfriend and we both thoroughly enjoyed the food. The service was pretty standard for England; jaded, no smiles, no information or opinions to offer so it's a good thing the food spoke for itself. We had:Jalapeno-Cashew Cheese Croquettes- very yummy but not very warmNachos- disappointing. oh well.Bangers and Mash- absolutely dee-lish!Sticky Toffee Pudding- HEAVENLY!!Half of the meal was average but the other half was so epic that it didn't matter! Seriously looking forward to coming back and trying other things!!
